 15720                                  ; ****************************************************************************
 15721                                  ; SYSINIT.BIN (MSDOS 6.21 IO.SYS) - RETRO DOS v4.0 by ERDOGAN TAN - 21/10/2022
 15722                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15723                                  ; Last Update: 04/01/2023 (Modified IO.SYS)  ((Previous: 30/12/2022))
 15724                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15725                                  ; Beginning: 03/06/2018 (Retro DOS 3.0), 21/03/2019 (Retro DOS 4.0)
 15726                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15727                                  ; Assembler: NASM version 2.15
 15728                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15729                                  ;	   ((nasm sysinit6.s -l sysinit6.lst -o SYSINIT6.BIN -Z error.txt)) 	
 15730                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15731                                  ; Modified from 'sysinit2.s' (SYSINIT2.BIN) file of Retro DOS v3.0 (6/7/2018)
 15732                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15733                                  ; Derived from 'SYSINIT1.ASM' and 'SYSINIT2.ASM' files of MSDOS 6.0
 15734                                  ; source code by Microsoft, 1991 
 15735                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15736                                  ; Derived from 'SYSINIT.ASM' file of MSDOS 2.0 (IBM PCDOS v2.0) source code
 15737                                  ; by Microsoft, 12/10/1983
 15738                                  ; ****************************************************************************
 15739                                  ; main file: 'retrodos4.s'
 15740                                  ; incbin 'SYSINIT3.BIN' ; (SYINITSEG)
 15741                                  
 15742                                  ; 30/12/2022 - Retro DOS v4.2 
 15743                                  ; Retro DOS v4.0 - 2019
 15744                                  ; SYSINIT (MSDOS 6.21 IO.SYS) draft: 'sysinit3.s' (01/07/2019)
 15745                                   
 15746                                  ; 21/10/2022
 15747                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15748                                  ; This source code (version) is based on SYSINIT source code of disassembled
 15749                                  ; MSDOS 5.0 IO.SYS file (SYSINIT.BIN) 
 15750                                  ; Dissassembler: Hex-Rays Interactive Disassembler (IDA)
 15751                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 15752                                  ; Binary file splitter & joiner: FFSJ v3.3
 15753                                  
 15754                                  ;--------------------------------------------------------------
 15755                                  ; SYSINIT.TXT (27/01/1983)
 15756                                  ;--------------------------------------------------------------
 15757                                  ;    SYSINIT is  a module linked behind the OEM bios.  It takes
 15758                                  ;over  the  system  initialization  after  the  OEM  bios   has
 15759                                  ;performed any  initialization  it  needs  to  do.   Control is
 15760                                  ;transfered with a long jump to the external  variable  SYSINIT
 15761                                  ;
 15762                                  ;
 15763                                  ;   The OEM  has  the  following  variables declared external:
 15764                                  ;
 15765                                  ;   CURRENT_DOS_LOCATION    WORD
 15766                                  ;
 15767                                  ;This word  contains  the  segment  number of the DOS before it
 15768                                  ;is relocated.  The OEM bios must set this value.
 15769                                  ;
 15770                                  ;   FINAL_DOS_LOCATION      WORD
 15771                                  ;
 15772                                  ;This word contains the segment number of the DOS after SYSINIT
 15773                                  ;moves it.  The OEM bios must set this value.
 15774                                  ;
 15775                                  ;   DEVICE_LIST             DWORD
 15776                                  ;
 15777                                  ;This  double  word  pointer  points  to  the  linked  list  of
 15778                                  ;character and block device drivers.  The  OEM  must  set  this
 15779                                  ;value.
 15780                                  ;
 15781                                  ;   MEMORY_SIZE             WORD
 15782                                  ;
 15783                                  ;This word  contains  the  number  of  RAM  paragraphs.  If the
 15784                                  ;bios doesn't set  this  variable  SYSINIT  will  automatically
 15785                                  ;calculate it.   NOTE:  systems with PARITY checked memory must
 15786                                  ;size memory in the BIOS.  SYSINITs method is to  write  memory
 15787                                  ;and read it back until it gets a mismatch.
 15788                                  ;
 15789                                  ;   DEFAULT_DRIVE           BYTE
 15790                                  ;
 15791                                  ;This is  the initial default drive when the system first comes
 15792                                  ;up.  drive a=0, drive b=1,  etc.   If  the  bios  doesn't  set
 15793                                  ;it then drive a is assumed.
 15794                                  ;
 15795                                  ;   BUFFERS                 BYTE
 15796                                  ;
 15797                                  ;This is  the  default  number of buffers for the system.  This
 15798                                  ;value may be overridden by the user in  the  CONFIG.SYS  file.
 15799                                  ;It is DBed to 2 in SYSINIT it should be greater than 1.
 15800                                  ;
 15801                                  ;   FILES                   BYTE
 15802                                  ;
 15803                                  ;This is  the  default  number  of  files for the system.  This
 15804                                  ;value may be overridden by the user in  the  CONFIG.SYS  file.
 15805                                  ;It is  DBed  to  8 in SYSINIT, values less than 5 are ignored.
 15806                                  ;
 15807                                  ;   SYSINIT                 FAR
 15808                                  ;
 15809                                  ;The entry  point  of  the  SYSINIT  module.  OEM BIOS jumps to
 15810                                  ;this label at the end of its INIT code.
 15811                                  ;
 15812                                  ;   The OEM  has  the  following  variables declared public:
 15813                                  ;
 15814                                  ;   RE_INIT                 FAR
 15815                                  ;
 15816                                  ;This is an entry point which allows the BIOS to do some INIT
 15817                                  ;work  after  the  DOS is initialized.  ALL REGISTERS MUST BE
 15818                                  ;PRESERVED.  On entry DS points to the first available memory
 15819                                  ;(after  the DOS).  DS:0 points to a 100H byte program header
 15820                                  ;prefix which represents  the  "program"  currently  running.
 15821                                  ;This  program  should  be  thought  of  as  the OEM BIOS and
 15822                                  ;SYSINIT taken together.  This is not  a  normal  program  in
 15823                                  ;that  no  memory  is  allocated to it, it is running in free
 15824                                  ;memory.
 15825                                  ;NOTES:
 15826                                  ;     At the time this routine is called SYSINIT occupies the
 15827                                  ;highest 10K of memory ("highest" is determined by the  value
 15828                                  ;of the MEMORY_SIZE variable), DO NOT DO WRITES THERE.
 15829                                  ;     Since this is called AFTER DOS is initialized, you can
 15830                                  ;make system calls.  This also implies that the code for this
 15831                                  ;routine    CANNOT   be   thrown   away   by   use   of   the
 15832                                  ;FINAL_DOS_LOCATION since the DOS has already been moved.
 15833                                  ;     If you don't want  anything done just set this to point
 15834                                  ;at a FAR RET instruction.
 15835                                  
 15836                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15837                                  ; TITLE   BIOS SYSTEM INITIALIZATION
 15838                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15839                                  
 15840                                  ;include version.inc
 15841                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15842                                  
 15843                                  ;FALSE   EQU     0
 15844                                  ;TRUE    EQU     0FFFFh
 15845                                  
 15846                                  ;IBMVER	    EQU     TRUE
 15847                                  ;IBMCOPYRIGHT EQU   FALSE
 15848                                  ;STACKSW    EQU	    TRUE		;Include Switchable Hardware Stacks
 15849                                  ;IBMJAPVER  EQU     FALSE		; If TRUE set KANJI true also
 15850                                  ;MSVER      EQU     FALSE
 15851                                  ;ALTVECT    EQU     FALSE		; Switch to build ALTVECT version
 15852                                  ;KANJI      EQU     FALSE
 15853                                  
 15854                                  ;(MSDOS 6.0, versiona.inc, 1991)
 15855                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15856                                  ;MAJOR_VERSION  EQU	6
 15857                                  ;;MINOR_VERSION	EQU	0	;6.00
 15858                                  ;MINOR_VERSION  EQU	21	;6.21  ; 21/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
 15859                                  
 15860                                  ; 22/10/2022 - Retro DOS v4.0 (Modified MSDOS 5.0)
 15861                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15862                                  ;MAJOR_VERSION   EQU	5
 15863                                  ;MINOR_VERSION   EQU	0
 15864                                  
 15865                                  ; 01/01/2023 - Retro DOS v4.2 (Modified MSDOS 6.21)
 15866                                  MAJOR_VERSION   EQU	6
 15867                                  MINOR_VERSION   EQU	22
 15868                                  
 15869                                  expected_version equ	(MINOR_VERSION<<8)+MAJOR_VERSION
 15870                                  
 15871                                  ;DOSREVNM equ	00000000b       ; m037 - bits 0-2 = revision number of DOS
 15872                                  				; currently 0.
 15873                                  DOSREVNM equ	00000111b	; [[[ 7 for Retro DOS v4.0 ]]] (21/03/2019)	
 15874                                  DOSINROM equ	00001000B       ; bit 3 of ver flags returned in BH
 15875                                  DOSINHMA equ	00010000B       ; bit 4 of ver flags 
 15876                                  
 15877                                  ;      if1
 15878                                  ;      %OUT  ... for DOS Version 5.00 ...
 15879                                  ;      endif
 15880                                  
 15881                                         ;******************************
 15882                                         ;Each assembler program should:
 15883                                         ;  mov ah,030h                   ;DOS Get Version function
 15884                                         ;  int 021h                      ;Version ret. in AX,minor version first
 15885                                         ;  cmp ax,expected_version       ;ALL utilities should check for an
 15886                                         ;  jne error_handler             ; EXACT version match.
 15887                                         ;******************************
 15888                                  
 15889                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15890                                  ; device definitions
 15891                                  
 15892                                  ;Attribute bit masks
 15893                                  DEVTYP  EQU     8000h           ;Bit 15 - 1  if Char, 0 if block
 15894                                  DEVIOCTL EQU    4000h           ;Bit 14 - CONTROL mode bit
 15895                                  ISFATBYDEV EQU  2000h           ;Bit 13 - Device uses FAT ID bytes, comp media.
 15896                                  ISCIN   EQU     0001h           ;Bit 0 - This device is the console input.
 15897                                  ISCOUT  EQU     0002h           ;Bit 1 - This device is the console output.
 15898                                  ISNULL  EQU     0004h           ;Bit 2 - This device is the null device.
 15899                                  ISCLOCK EQU     0008h           ;Bit 3 - This device is the clock device.
 15900                                  ISIBM   EQU     0010h           ;Bit 4 - This device is special
 15901                                  
 15902                                  ; The device table list has the form:
 15903                                  struc	SYSDEV
 15904 00000000 ????????                .NEXT:		resd 1		;Pointer to next device header
 15905 00000004 ????                    .ATT:		resw 1		;Attributes of the device
 15906 00000006 ????                    .STRAT:		resw 1		;Strategy entry point
 15907 00000008 ????                    .INT:		resw 1		;Interrupt entry point
 15908 0000000A ????????????????        .NAME:		resb 8		;Name of device (only first byte used for block)
 15909                                  .size:
 15910                                  endstruc
 15911                                  
 15912                                  ;Static Reguest Header
 15913                                  struc	SRHEAD
 15914 00000000 ??                      .REQLEN:	resb 1		;Length in bytes of request block
 15915 00000001 ??                      .REQUNIT:	resb 1		;Device unit number
 15916 00000002 ??                      .REQFUNC:	resb 1		;Type of request
 15917 00000003 ????                    .REQSTAT:	resw 1		;Status Word
 15918 00000005 ????????????????                	resb 8		;Reserved for queue links
 15919                                  .size:
 15920                                  endstruc
 15921                                  
 15922                                  ;Status word masks
 15923                                  STERR   EQU     8000H           ;Bit 15 - Error
 15924                                  STBUI   EQU     0200H           ;Bit 9 - Buisy
 15925                                  STDON   EQU     0100H           ;Bit 8 - Done
 15926                                  STECODE EQU     00FFH           ;Error code
 15927                                  WRECODE EQU     0
 15928                                  
 15929                                  ;Function codes
 15930                                  DEVINIT EQU     0               ;Initialization
 15931                                  DINITHL EQU     26              ;Size of init header
 15932                                  DEVMDCH EQU     1               ;Media check
 15933                                  DMEDHL  EQU     15              ;Size of media check header
 15934                                  DEVBPB  EQU     2               ;Get BPB
 15935                                  DEVRDIOCTL EQU  3               ;IOCTL read
 15936                                  DBPBHL  EQU     22              ;Size of Get BPB header
 15937                                  DEVRD   EQU     4               ;Read
 15938                                  DRDWRHL EQU     22              ;Size of RD/WR header
 15939                                  DEVRDND EQU     5               ;Non destructive read no wait (character devs)
 15940                                  DRDNDHL EQU     14              ;Size of non destructive read header
 15941                                  DEVIST  EQU     6               ;Input status
 15942                                  DSTATHL EQU     13              ;Size of status header
 15943                                  DEVIFL  EQU     7               ;Input flush
 15944                                  DFLSHL  EQU     15              ;Size of flush header
 15945                                  DEVWRT  EQU     8               ;Write
 15946                                  DEVWRTV EQU     9               ;Write with verify
 15947                                  DEVOST  EQU     10              ;Output status
 15948                                  DEVOFL  EQU     11              ;Output flush
 15949                                  DEVWRIOCTL EQU  12              ;IOCTL write
 15950                                  
 15951                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15952                                  struc	SYS_FCB
 15953 00000000 ??                      .fcb_drive:	resb 1
 15954 00000001 ????????????????        .fcb_name:	resb 8
 15955 00000009 ??????                  .fcb_ext:	resb 3
 15956 0000000C ????                    .fcb_EXTENT:	resw 1
 15957 0000000E ????                    .fcb_RECSIZ:	resw 1	; Size of record (user settable)
 15958 00000010 ????                    .fcb_FILSIZ:	resw 1	; Size of file in bytes; used with the following
 15959                                                          ; word
 15960 00000012 ????                    .fcb_DRVBP:	resw 1	; BP for SEARCH FIRST and SEARCH NEXT
 15961 00000014 ????                    .fcb_FDATE:	resw 1	; Date of last writing
 15962 00000016 ????                    .fcb_FTIME:	resw 1	; Time of last writing
 15963 00000018 ??                      .fcb_DEVID:	resb 1	; Device ID number, bits 0-5 if file.
 15964                                                          ; bit 7=0 for file, bit 7=1 for I/O device
 15965                                                          ; If file, bit 6=0 if dirty
 15966                                                          ; If I/O device, bit 6=0 if EOF (input)
 15967                                                          ;               Bit 5=1 if Raw mode
 15968                                                          ;               Bit 0=1 if console input device
 15969                                                          ;               Bit 1=1 if console output device
 15970                                                          ;               Bit 2=1 if null device
 15971                                                          ;               Bit 3=1 if clock device
 15972 00000019 ????                    .fcb_FIRCLUS:	resw 1	; First cluster of file
 15973 0000001B ????                    .fcb_CLUSPOS:	resw 1	; Position of last cluster accessed
 15974 0000001D ????                    .fcb_LSTCLUS:	resw 1	; Last cluster accessed and directory
 15975 0000001F ??                                   	resb 1	; pack 2 12 bit numbers into 24 bits...
 15976 00000020 ??                      .fcb_NR:	resb 1	; Next record
 15977 00000021 ????????                .fcb_RR:	resb 4	; Random record
 15978                                  .size:
 15979                                  endstruc
 15980                                  
 15981                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 15982                                  ; Field definition for I/O buffer information
 15983                                  
 15984                                  ; 22/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0 (MSDOS 6.0, BUFFER.INC, 1991)
 15985                                  
 15986                                  struc buffinfo
 15987 00000000 ????                    .buf_next:	resw 1	; Pointer to next buffer in list
 15988 00000002 ????                    .buf_prev:	resw 1	; Pointer to previous buffer in list
 15989 00000004 ??                      .buf_ID:	resb 1	; Drive of buffer (bit 7 = 0)
 15990                                  			; SFT table index (bit 7 = 1)
 15991                                  			; = FFh if buffer free
 15992 00000005 ??                      .buf_flags:	resb 1	; Bit 7 = 1 if Remote file buffer
 15993                                  			;	= 0 if Local device buffer
 15994                                  			; Bit 6 = 1 if buffer dirty
 15995                                  			; Bit 5 = Reserved
 15996                                  			; Bit 4 = Search bit (bit 7 = 1)
 15997                                  			; Bit 3 = 1 if buffer is DATA
 15998                                  			; Bit 2 = 1 if buffer is DIR
 15999                                  			; Bit 1 = 1 if buffer is FAT
 16000                                  			; Bit 0 = Reserved
 16001 00000006 ????????                .buf_sector:	resd 1	; Sector number of buffer (bit 7 = 0)
 16002                                  ; The next two items are often refed as a word (bit 7 = 0)
 16003 0000000A ??                      .buf_wrtcnt:	resb 1	; For FAT sectors, # times sector written out
 16004 0000000B ????                    .buf_wrtcntinc:	resw 1	; "   "     "   , # sectors between each write
 16005 0000000D ????????                .buf_DPB :	resd 1	; Pointer to drive parameters
 16006 00000011 ????                    .buf_fill:	resw 1	; How full buffer is (bit 7 = 1)
 16007 00000013 ??                      .buf_reserved:	resb 1	; make DWORD boundary for 386
 16008                                  .size:
 16009                                  endstruc
 16010                                  
 16011                                  %define buf_offset	dword [buf_sector]
 16012                                  			;For bit 7 = 1, this is the byte
 16013                                  			;offset of the start of the buffer in
 16014                                  			;the file pointed to by buf_ID.  Thus
 16015                                  			;the buffer starts at location
 16016                                  			;buf_offset in the file and contains
 16017                                  			;buf_fill bytes.
 16018                                  
 16019                                  bufinsiz	equ	buffinfo.size ; ; Size of structure in bytes
 16020                                  
 16021                                  
 16022                                  buf_Free	equ	0FFh		; buf_id of free buffer
 16023                                  
 16024                                  ;Flag byte masks
 16025                                  buf_isnet	EQU	10000000B
 16026                                  buf_dirty	EQU	01000000B
 16027                                  ;***
 16028                                  buf_visit	EQU	00100000B
 16029                                  ;***
 16030                                  buf_snbuf	EQU	00010000B
 16031                                  
 16032                                  buf_isDATA	EQU	00001000B
 16033                                  buf_isDIR	EQU	00000100B
 16034                                  buf_isFAT	EQU	00000010B
 16035                                  buf_type_0	EQU	11110001B	; AND sets type to "none"
 16036                                  
 16037                                  buf_NetID	EQU	bufinsiz
 16038                                  
 16039                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16040                                  
 16041                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16042                                  ;**	DPB - Drive Parameter Block
 16043                                  
 16044                                  ; 25/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0 (MSDOS 6.0, DPB.INC, 1991)
 16045                                  
 16046                                  ;	BUGBUG - this isn't authorative - it's my probably incomplete and
 16047                                  ;	possibly inaccurate deductions from code study... - jgl
 16048                                  ;
 16049                                  ;	The DPB is DOS's main structure for describing block devices.
 16050                                  ;	It contains info about the "Drive" intermingled with info about
 16051                                  ;	the FAT file system which is presumably on the drive.  I don't know
 16052                                  ;	how those fields are used if it's not the FAT file system - BUGBUG
 16053                                  ;
 16054                                  ;	The DPBs are statically allocated and chained off of DPBHead.
 16055                                  ;	Users scan this chain looking for a match on DPB_DRIVE.
 16056                                  ;	The DPBs are built at init time from info in the SYSDEV structure.
 16057                                  
 16058                                  ; 08/06/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0 (MSDOS 3.3, DPB.INC, 24/07/1987)
 16059                                  
 16060                                  ; 12/05/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
 16061                                  
 16062                                  struc	DPB
 16063 00000000 ??                      .DRIVE:		resb 1		; Logical drive # assoc with DPB (A=0,B=1,...)
 16064 00000001 ??                      .UNIT:		resb 1		; Driver unit number of DPB
 16065 00000002 ????                    .SECTOR_SIZE:	resw 1		; Size of physical sector in bytes
 16066 00000004 ??                      .CLUSTER_MASK:	resb 1		; Sectors/cluster - 1
 16067 00000005 ??                      .CLUSTER_SHIFT:	resb 1		; Log2 of sectors/cluster
 16068 00000006 ????                    .FIRST_FAT:	resw 1		; Starting record of FATs
 16069 00000008 ??                      .FAT_COUNT:	resb 1		; Number of FATs for this drive
 16070 00000009 ????                    .ROOT_ENTRIES:	resw 1		; Number of directory entries
 16071 0000000B ????                    .FIRST_SECTOR:	resw 1		; First sector of first cluster
 16072 0000000D ????                    .MAX_CLUSTER:	resw 1		; Number of clusters on drive + 1
 16073                                  ;.FAT_SIZE:	resb 1  ; MSDOS 3.3
 16074 0000000F ????                    .FAT_SIZE:	resw 1		; Number of records occupied by FAT
 16075 00000011 ????                    .DIR_SECTOR:	resw 1		; Starting record of directory
 16076 00000013 ????????                .DRIVER_ADDR:	resd 1		; Pointer to driver
 16077 00000017 ??                      .MEDIA:		resb 1		; Media byte
 16078 00000018 ??                      .FIRST_ACCESS:	resb 1		; This is initialized to -1 to force a media
 16079                                  				; check the first time this DPB is used
 16080 00000019 ????????                .NEXT_DPB:	resd 1		; Pointer to next Drive parameter block
 16081 0000001D ????                    .NEXT_FREE:	resw 1		; Cluster # of last allocated cluster
 16082 0000001F ????                    .FREE_CNT:	resw 1		; Count of free clusters, -1 if unknown
 16083                                  .size:
 16084                                  endstruc
 16085                                  
 16086                                  DPBSIZ  EQU     DPB.size	; Size of the structure in bytes
 16087                                  
 16088                                  DSKSIZ  EQU	DPB.MAX_CLUSTER	; Size of disk (temp used during init only)
 16089

 16140 00000000 ????                    .ST_SECTORNUMBER:	resw	1

 16145                                  ; 25/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0  (MSDOS 6.0, BPB.INC, IOCTL.INC)
 16146                                  
 16147                                  ;**	BIOS PARAMETER BLOCK DEFINITION
 16148                                  ;
 16149                                  ;	The BPB contains information about the disk structure.  It dates
 16150                                  ;	back to the earliest FAT systems and so FAT information is
 16151                                  ;	intermingled with physical driver information.
 16152                                  ;
 16153                                  ;	A boot sector contains a BPB for its device; for other disks
 16154                                  ;	the driver creates a BPB.  DOS keeps copies of some of this
 16155                                  ;	information in the DPB.
 16156                                  ;
 16157                                  ;	The BDS structure contains a BPB within it.
 16158                                  
 16159                                  struc A_BPB
 16160 00000000 ????                    .BPB_BYTESPERSECTOR:	resw	1
 16161 00000002 ??                      .BPB_SECTORSPERCLUSTER:	resb	1
 16162 00000003 ????                    .BPB_RESERVEDSECTORS:	resw	1
 16163 00000005 ??                      .BPB_NUMBEROFFATS:	resb	1
 16164 00000006 ????                    .BPB_ROOTENTRIES: 	resw	1
 16165 00000008 ????                    .BPB_TOTALSECTORS:	resw	1
 16166 0000000A ??                      .BPB_MEDIADESCRIPTOR:	resb	1
 16167 0000000B ????                    .BPB_SECTORSPERFAT:	resw	1
 16168 0000000D ????                    .BPB_SECTORSPERTRACK:	resw	1
 16169 0000000F ????                    .BPB_HEADS:		resw	1
 16170 00000011 ????                    .BPB_HIDDENSECTORS:	resw	1
 16171 00000013 ????                    			resw	1
 16172 00000015 ????                    .BPB_BIGTOTALSECTORS:	resw	1
 16173 00000017 ????                    			resw	1
 16174 00000019 ????????????            			resb	6	; NOTE:  many times these
 16175                                  ;					; 	 6 bytes are omitted
 16176                                  ;					;	 when BPB manipulations
 16177                                  ;					;	 are performed!
 16178                                  .size:
 16179                                  endstruc
 16180                                  
 16181                                  struc A_DEVICEPARAMETERS
 16182 00000000 ??                      .DP_SPECIALFUNCTIONS:	resb	1
 16183 00000001 ??                      .DP_DEVICETYPE:		resb	1
 16184 00000002 ????                    .DP_DEVICEATTRIBUTES:	resw	1
 16185 00000004 ????                    .DP_CYLINDERS:		resw	1
 16186 00000006 ??                      .DP_MEDIATYPE:		resb	1
 16187 00000007 <res 1Fh>               .DP_BPB:		resb	A_BPB.size
 16188 00000026 ????                    .DP_TRACKTABLEENTRIES:	resw	1
 16189 00000028 <res FCh>               .DP_SECTORTABLE:	resb	MAX_SECTORS_IN_TRACK * A_SECTORTABLE.size
 16190                                  endstruc

 16255 00000005 ??????????              .CPM_CALL:	resb 5		; ancient call to system
 16256 0000000A ????????                .EXIT:		resd 1		; pointer to exit routine
 16257 0000000E ????????                .CTRL_C:	resd 1		; pointer to ^C routine
 16258 00000012 ????????                .FATAL_ABORT:	resd 1		; pointer to fatal error
 16259 00000016 ????                    .PARENT_PID:	resw 1		; PID of parent (terminate PID)
 16260 00000018 <res 14h>               .JFN_TABLE:     resb FILPERPROC ; indices into system table
 16261 0000002C ????                    .ENVIRON:	resw 1		; seg addr of environment
 16262 0000002E ????????                .USER_STACK:	resd 1		; stack of self during system calls
 16263 00000032 ????                    .JFN_LENGTH:	resw 1 		; number of handles allowed
 16264 00000034 ????????                .JFN_POINTER:	resd 1 		; pointer to JFN table

 16268 0000003E ????                    .NOVELL_USED:	resb 2		; Novell shell (redir) uses these
 16269 00000040 ????                    .VERSION:	resw 1		; DOS version reported to this app
 16270 00000042 <res Eh>                .PAD1:		resb 14		; 	
 16271 00000050 ??????????              .CALL_SYSTEM:	resb 5		; portable method of system call
 16272 00000055 ??????????????          .PAD2:		resb 7 		; reserved so FCB 1 can be used as an extended FCB
 16273 0000005C <res 10h>               .FCB1:		resb 16		; default FCB 1
 16274 0000006C <res 10h>               .FCB2:		resb 16		; default FCB 2
 16275 0000007C ????????                .PAD3:		resb 4		; not sure if this is used by PDB_FCB2
 16276 00000080 <res 80h>               .TAIL:		resb 128	; command tail and default DTA
 16277                                  ;.size:
 16278                                  endstruc

 16438                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16439                                  ; BIOSTRUC.INC (MSDOS 3.3 - 24/07/1987) 	
 16440                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16441                                  					  ;;Rev 3.30 Modification
 16442                                  ; ROM BIOS CALL PACKET STRUCTURES					  
 16443                                  									  
 16444                                  ;*******************************					  
 16445                                  ;System Service call ( Int 15h )					  
 16446                                  ;*******************************					  
 16447                                  ;Function AH = 0C0h, Return system configuration			  
 16448                                  ;For PC and PCJR on return:						  
 16449                                  ;	(AH)	= 80h							  
 16450                                  ;	(CY)	= 1							  
 16451                                  ;For PCXT, PC PORTABLE and PCAT on return:				  
 16452                                  ;	(AH)	= 86h							  
 16453                                  ;	(CY)	= 1							  
 16454                                  ;For all others:							  
 16455                                  ;	(AH)	= 0							  
 16456                                  ;	(CY)	= 0							  
 16457                                  ;	(ES:BX) = pointer to system descriptor vector in ROS		  
 16458                                  ; System descriptor :							  
 16459                                  ;	DW	xxxx		length of descriptor in bytes,		  
 16460                                  ;				minimum length = 8			  
 16461                                  ;	DB	xx		model byte				  
 16462                                  ;				0FFh	= PC				  
 16463                                  ;				0FEh	= PC/XT, Portable		  
 16464                                  ;				0FDh	= PC/JR 			  
 16465                                  ;				0FCh	= PC/AT				  
 16466                                  ;				0F9h	= Convertable			  
 16467                                  ;				0F8h	= Model 80			  
 16468                                  ;				0E0 thru 0EFh = reserved		  
 16469                                  ;									  
 16470                                  ;	DB	xx		secondary model byte			  
 16471                                  ;				000h	= PC1				  
 16472                                  ;				000h	= PC/XT, Portable		  
 16473                                  ;				000h	= PC/JR 			  
 16474                                  ;				000h	= PC/AT 			  
 16475                                  ;				001h	= PC/AT Model 339		  
 16476                                  ;				003h	= PC/RT				  
 16477                                  ;				000h	= Convertable			  
 16478                                  ;									  
 16479                                  ;	DB	xx		bios revision level			  
 16480                                  ;				00 for first release, subsequent release  
 16481                                  ;				of code with same model byte and	  
 16482                                  ;				secondary model byte require revison level
 16483                                  ;				to increase by one.			  
 16484                                  ;									  
 16485                                  ;	DB	xx		feature information byte 1		  
 16486                                  ;				X0000000 = 1, bios use DMA channel 3	  
 16487                                  ;					 = 0, DMA channel 3 not used	  
 16488                                  ;									  
 16489                                  ;				0X000000 = 1, 2nd Interrupt chip present  
 16490                                  ;					 = 0, 2nd Interrupt chip not present
 16491                                  ;									  
 16492                                  ;				00X00000 = 1, Real Time Clock present	  
 16493                                  ;					 = 0, Real Time Clock not present 
 16494                                  ;

 16629                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16630                                  ; CURDIR.INC (MSDOS 6.0 - 1991) 	
 16631                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16632                                  ; 22/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
 16633                                  
 16634                                  ;**	CDS - Current Directory Structure
 16635                                  ;
 16636                                  ; CDS items are used bu the internal routines to store cluster numbers and
 16637                                  ; network identifiers for each logical name.  The ID field is used dually,
 16638                                  ; both as net ID and for a cluster number for local devices. In the case
 16639                                  ; of local devices, the cluster number will be -1 if there is a potential
 16640                                  ; of the disk being changed or if the path must be recracked.
 16641                                  ;
 16642                                  ;	Some pathnames have special preambles, such as
 16643                                  ;
 16644                                  ;		\\machine\sharename\...
 16645                                  ;	For these pathnames we can't allow ".." processing to back us
 16646                                  ;	up into the special front part of the name.  The CURDIR_END field
 16647                                  ;	holds the address of the seperator character which marks
 16648                                  ;	the split between the special preamble and the regular
 16649                                  ;	path list; ".." processing isn't allowed to back us up past
 16650                                  ;	(i.e., before) CURDIR_END
 16651                                  ;	For the root, it points at the leading /. For net
 16652                                  ;	assignments it points at the end (nul) of the initial assignment:
 16653                                  ;	A:/	\\foo\bar	    \\foo\bar\blech\bozo
 16654                                  ;	  ^		 ^		     ^
 16655                                  
 16656                                  DIRSTRLEN	EQU	64+3		; Max length in bytes of directory strings
 16657                                  TEMPLEN 	EQU	DIRSTRLEN*2
 16658                                  
 16659                                  struc 		curdir_list
 16660                                  ; MSDOS 3.3
 16661 00000000 <res 43h>               .cdir_text	resb	DIRSTRLEN	; text of assignment and curdir
 16662 00000043 ????                    .cdir_flags	resw	1		; various flags
 16663 00000045 ????????                .cdir_devptr	resd	1		; local pointer to DPB or net device
 16664 00000049 ????????                .cdir_ID	resw	2		; cluster of current dir (net ID)
 16665 0000004D ????                    .cdir_usr_word	resw	1
 16666 0000004F ????                    .cdir_end	resw	1		; end of assignment
 16667                                  ; MSDOS 6.0
 16668 00000051 ??                      .cdir_type:	resb	1		; IFS drive (2=ifs, 4=netuse)
 16669 00000052 ????????                .cdir_ifd_hdr:	resd	1		; Ptr to File System Header
 16670 00000056 ????                    .cdir_fsda:	resb	2		; File System Dependent Data Area
 16671                                  .size:
 16672                                  endstruc
 16673                                  
 16674                                  curdirlen	EQU	curdir_list.size	; Needed for screwed up
 16675                                  						; ASM87 which doesn't allow
 16676                                  						; Size directive as a macro
 16677                                  						; argument
 16678                                  %define curdir_netID	dword [curdir_list.cdir_ID]
 16679                                  
 16680                                  ;**	Flag values for CURDIR_FLAGS
 16681                                  
 16682                                  ;Flag word masks
 16683                                  curdir_isnet	EQU	1000000000000000B
 16684                                  curdir_isifs	EQU	1000000000000000B
 16685                                  curdir_inuse	EQU	0100000000000000B
 16686                                  curdir_splice	EQU	0010000000000000B
 16687                                  curdir_local	EQU	0001000000000000B

 16689                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16690                                  ; SF.INC (MSDOS 6.0 - 1991) 	
 16691                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 16692                                  ; 25/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
 16693                                  
 16694                                  ; system file table
 16695                                  
 16696                                  ;**	System File Table SuperStructure
 16697                                  ;
 16698                                  ;	The system file table entries are allocated in contiguous groups.
 16699                                  ;	There may be more than one such groups; the SF "superstructure"
 16700                                  ;	tracks the groups.
 16701                                  
 16702                                  struc	SF
 16703 00000000 ????????                .SFLink:	resd	1
 16704 00000004 ????                    .SFCount:	resw	1		; number of entries
 16705 00000006 ????                    .SFTable:	resw	1		; beginning of array of the following
 16706                                  .size:
 16707                                  endstruc
 16708                                  
 16709                                  ;**	System file table entry
 16710                                  ;
 16711                                  ;	These are the structures which are at SFTABLE in the SF structure.
 16712                                  
 16713                                  struc	SF_ENTRY
 16714 00000000 ????                    .sf_ref_count:	resw	1		; number of processes sharing entry
 16715                                  					;   if FCB then ref count
 16716 00000002 ????                    .sf_mode: 	resw	1		; mode of access or high bit on if FCB
 16717 00000004 ??                      .sf_attr: 	resb	1		; attribute of file
 16718 00000005 ????                    .sf_flags:	resw	1		;Bits 8-15
 16719                                  					; Bit 15 = 1 if remote file
 16720                                  					;	 = 0 if local file or device
 16721                                  					; Bit 14 = 1 if date/time is not to be
 16722                                  					;   set from clock at CLOSE.  Set by
 16723                                  					;   FILETIMES and FCB_CLOSE.  Reset by
 16724                                  					;   other reseters of the dirty bit
 16725                                  					;   (WRITE)
 16726                                  					; Bit 13 = Pipe bit (reserved)
 16727                                  					;
 16728                                  					; Bits 0-7 (old FCB_devid bits)
 16729                                  					; If remote file or local file, bit
 16730                                  					; 6=0 if dirty Device ID number, bits
 16731                                  					; 0-5 if local file.
 16732                                  					; bit 7=0 for local file, bit 7
 16733                                  					;      =1 for local I/O device
 16734                                  					; If local I/O device, bit 6=0 if EOF (input)
 16735                                  					;		Bit 5=1 if Raw mode
 16736                                  					;		Bit 0=1 if console input device
 16737                                  					;		Bit 1=1 if console output device
 16738                                  					;		Bit 2=1 if null device
 16739                                  					;		Bit 3=1 if clock device
 16740 00000007 ????????                .sf_devptr:	resd	1		; Points to DPB if local file, points
 16741                                  					; to device header if local device,
 16742                                  					; points to net device header if
 16743                                  					; remote
 16744 0000000B ????                    .sf_firclus:	resw	1		; First cluster of file (bit 15 = 0)
 16745                                  ;.sf_lstclus:	resw	1 ; *	
 16746 0000000D ????                    .sf_time: 	resw	1		; Time associated with file
 16747 0000000F ????                    .sf_date: 	resw	1		; Date associated with file
 16748 00000011 ????????                .sf_size: 	resd	1		; Size associated with file
 16749 00000015 ????????                .sf_position:	resd	1		; Read/Write pointer or LRU count for FCBs
 16750                                  ;
 16751                                  ; Starting here, the next 7 bytes may be used by the file system to store an
 16752                                  ; ID
 16753                                  ;
 16754 00000019 ????                    .sf_cluspos:	resw	1		; Position of last cluster accessed
 16755 0000001B ????                    .sf_dirsec:	resw	1		; Sector number of directory sector for this file
 16756 0000001D ??                      .sf_dirpos:	resb	1		; Offset of this entry in the above
 16757                                  ;
 16758                                  ; End of 7 bytes of file-system specific info.
 16759                                  ;
 16760 0000001E <res Bh>                .sf_name:	resb	11		; 11 character name that is in the
 16761                                  					; directory entry.  This is used by
 16762                                  					; close to detect file deleted and
 16763                                  					; disk changed errors.
 16764                                  ; SHARING INFO
 16765 00000029 ????????                .sf_chain:	resd	1		; link to next SF
 16766 0000002D ????                    .sf_UID:	resw	1
 16767 0000002F ????                    .sf_PID:	resw	1
 16768 00000031 ????                    .sf_MFT:	resw	1
 16769 00000033 ????                    .sf_lstclus:	resw	1 ; *		; Last cluster accessed
 16770 00000035 ????????                .sf_IFS_HDR:	resd 	1 ; **
 16771                                  .size:
 16772                                  endstruc
 16773

 17044                                  	;IF	STACKSW 
 17045                                  	; include MSSTACK.INC	;Main stack program and data definitions

 17051                                  ; 05/07/2018
 17052                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 17053                                  ; 04/06/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0
 17054                                  
 17055                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 17056                                  ; 21/10/2022 - Retro DOS v4.0 (Modified MSDOS 5.0 IO.SYS - SYSINIT)
 17057                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 17058                                  
 17059                                  ;	MSStack.inc
 17060                                  ;
 17061                                  ;	Interrupt level 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7,(10, 11, 12, 14, 15 - AT level)
 17062                                  ;	should follow the standard Interrupt Sharing Scheme which has
 17063                                  ;	a standard header structure.
 17064                                  ;	Fyi, the following shows the relations between
 17065                                  ;	the interrupt vector and interrupt level.
 17066                                  ; VEC(Hex)    2  8  9  A  B  C	D  E  70  72  73  74  76  77
 17067                                  ; LVL(Deci)   9  0  1  2  3  4	5  6   8  10  11  12  14  15
 17068                                  ;	MSSTACK module modifies the following interrupt vectors
 17069                                  ;	to meet the standard Interrupt Sharing standard;
 17070                                  ;	  A, B, C, D, E, 72, 73, 74, 76, 77.
 17071                                  ;	Also, for interrupt level 7 and 15, the FirstFlag in a standard header
 17072                                  ;	should be initialized to indicat whether this interrupt handler is
 17073                                  ;	the first (= 80h) or not.  The FirstFlag entry of INT77h's
 17074                                  ;	program header is initialized in STKINIT.INC module.
 17075                                  ;	FirstFlag is only meaningful for interrupt level 7 and 15.
 17076                                  ;
 17077                                  
 17078                                  ;  User specifies the number of stack elements - default = 9
 17079                                  ;						 minimum = 8
 17080                                  ;						 maximum = 64
 17081                                  ;
 17082                                  ;  Intercepts Asynchronous Hardware Interrupts only
 17083                                  ;
 17084                                  ;  Picks a stack from pool of stacks and switches to it
 17085                                  ;
 17086                                  ;  Calls the previously saved interrupt vector after pushing flags
 17087                                  ;
 17088                                  ;  On return, returns the stack to the stack pool
 17089                                  ;
 17090                                  
 17091                                  ; This is a modification of STACKS:
 17092                                  ; 1. To fix a bug which was causing the program to take up too much space.
 17093                                  ; 2. To dispense stack space from hi-mem first rather than low-mem first.
 17094                                  ;    . Clobbers the stack that got too big instead of innocent stack
 17095                                  ;    . Allows system to work if the only stack that got too big was the most
 17096                                  ;      deeply nested one
 17097                                  ; 3. Disables NMI interrupts while setting the NMI vector.
 17098                                  ; 4. Does not intercept any interupts on a PCjr.
 17099                                  ; 5. Double checks that a nested interrupt didn't get the same stack.
 17100                                  ; 6. Intercepts Ints 70, 72-77 for PC-ATs and other future products
 17101                                  
 17102                                  		;EVEN
 17103                                  ;align 2
 17104                                  		; 21/10/2022
 17105                                  
 17106 00000000 0000                    		dw	0	; spare field but leave these in order
 17107 00000002 0000                    stackcount:	dw	0
 17108 00000004 0000                    stackat: 	dw	0
 17109 00000006 0000                    stacksize:	dw	0
 17110 00000008 0000                    stacks:		dw	0
 17111 0000000A 0000                    		dw	0
 17112                                  
 17113 0000000C [0800]                  firstentry:	dw	stacks
 17114 0000000E [4800]                  lastentry:	dw	stacks+(defaultcount*entrysize)-entrysize
 17115 00000010 [4800]                  nextentry:	dw	stacks+(defaultcount*entrysize)-entrysize
 17116                                  
 17117                                  ;***********************************************************************
 17118                                  ; THESE ARE THE INDIVIDUAL INTERRUPT HANDLERS
 17119                                  
 17120                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 17121                                  
 17122 00000012 00000000                old02:	dd	0
 17123                                  
 17124                                  int02:
 17125                                  
 17126                                  ; *********************************************************************
 17127                                  ;
 17128                                  ; this is special support for the pc convertible / nmi handler
 17129                                  ;
 17130                                  ;	on the pc convertible, there is a situation where an nmi can be 
 17131                                  ;	caused by using the "out" instructions to certain ports. when this
 17132                                  ;	occurs, the pc convertible hardware *guarantees* that **nothing** 
 17133                                  ;	can stop the nmi or interfere with getting to the nmi handler. this
 17134                                  ;	includes other type of interrupts (hardware and software), and
 17135                                  ;	also includes other type of nmi's. when any nmi has occured,
 17136                                  ;	no other interrtupt (hardware, software or nmi) can occur until
 17137                                  ;	the software takes specific steps to allow further interrupting.
 17138                                  ;
 17139                                  ;	for pc convertible, the situation where the nmi is generated by the
 17140                                  ;	"out" to a control port requires "fixing-up" and re-attempting. in
 17141                                  ;	otherwords, it is actually a "restartable exception". in this
 17142                                  ;	case, the software handler must be able to get to the stack in
 17143                                  ;	order to figure out what instruction caused the problem, where
 17144                                  ;	it was "out"ing to and what value it was "out"ing.  therefore,
 17145                                  ;	we will not switch stacks in this situation. this situation is
 17146                                  ;	detected by interrogating port 62h, and checking for a bit value
 17147                                  ;	of 80h. if set, *****do not switch stacks*****.
 17148                                  ;
 17149                                  ; *********************************************************************
 17150                                  
 17151 00000016 50                      	push	ax
 17152 00000017 06                      	push	es
 17153 00000018 B800F0                  	mov	ax,0F000h
 17154 0000001B 8EC0                    	mov	es,ax
 17155                                  	; 02/11/2022
 17156 0000001D 26803EFEFFF9            	cmp	byte [es:0FFFEh],0F9h ; mdl_convert ; check if convertible
 17157 00000023 07                      	pop	es
 17158 00000024 750C                    	jne	short normal02
 17159                                  
 17160 00000026 E462                    	in	al,62h		; PC/XT PPI port C. Bits:
 17161                                  				; 0-3: values of DIP switches
 17162                                  				; 5: 1=Timer 2 channel out
 17163                                  				; 6: 1=I/O channel check
 17164                                  				; 7: 1=RAM parity check error occurred.
 17165 00000028 A880                    	test	al,80h
 17166 0000002A 7406                    	jz	short normal02
 17167                                  special02:
 17168 0000002C 58                      	pop	ax
 17169 0000002D 2EFF2E[1200]            	jmp	far [cs:old02]
 17170                                  normal02:
 17171 00000032 58                      	pop	ax
 17172 00000033 E81101                  	call	do_int_stacks
 17173 00000036 [1200]                  	dw	old02

 17401                                  ;********************************************************************
 17402                                  ;common routines
 17403                                  ;********************************************************************
 17404                                  
 17405                                  ; do interrupt stack switching. the fake return address holds
 17406                                  ; a pointer to the far-pointer of the actual interrupt
 17407                                  ; service routine
 17408                                  
 17409                                  ; 21/10/2022 - Retro DOS v4.0 (Modified MSDOS 5.0 SYSINIT)
 17410                                  ; 21/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
 17411                                  
 17412                                  ;allocbyte   equ 0
 17413                                  ;intlevel    equ 1
 17414                                  ;savedsp     equ 2
 17415                                  ;savedss     equ 4
 17416                                  ;newsp       equ 6
 17417                                  
 17418                                  ; 30/12/2022 - Retro DOS v4.2 (Modified MSDOS 6.21 SYSINIT)
 17419                                  ; (MSDOS 6.21 IO:SYS, SYSINIT:0147h)
 17420                                  
 17421                                  do_int_stacks:
 17422 00000147 50                      	push	ax
 17423 00000148 55                      	push	bp
 17424 00000149 06                      	push	es
 17425 0000014A 2E8E06[0A00]            	mov	es,[cs:stacks+2]	; Get segment of stacks
 17426 0000014F 2E8B2E[1000]            	mov	bp,[cs:nextentry]	; get most likely candidate
 17427 00000154 B001                    	mov	al,allocated ; 1
 17428                                  	; 21/10/2022
 17429                                  	;xchg	[es:bp+allocbyte],al 
 17430                                  	; 11/12/2022
 17431 00000156 26864600                	xchg	[es:bp],al		; grab the entry
 17432 0000015A 3C00                    	cmp	al,free ; 0		; still avail?
 17433 0000015C 7551                    	jne	short notfree02
 17434                                  
 17435 0000015E 2E832E[1000]08          	sub	word [cs:nextentry],entrysize ; set for next interrupt
 17436                                  
 17437                                  found02:
 17438 00000164 26896602                	mov	[es:bp+savedsp],sp	; save sp value
 17439 00000168 268C5604                	mov	[es:bp+savedss],ss	; save ss also
 17440                                  
 17441 0000016C 89E8                    	mov	ax,bp			; temp save of table offset
 17442                                  
 17443 0000016E 268B6E06                	mov	bp,[es:bp+newsp]	; get new SP value
 17444                                  	; 21/10/2022
 17445                                  	;mov	bp,[es:bp+6]
 17446                                  	; 11/12/2022
 17447                                  	;cmp	[es:bp+0],ax	
 17448 00000172 26394600                	cmp	[es:bp],ax		; check for offset into table
 17449 00000176 7544                    	jne	short foundbad02
 17450                                  
 17451                                  	; 02/07/2023 (MSDOS 6.21 SYSINIT code)
 17452 00000178 8CC0                    	mov	ax,es			; point ss,sp to the new stack
 17453 0000017A 8EC5                    	mov	es,bp
 17454 0000017C 89E5                    	mov	bp,sp
 17455 0000017E 8B6E06                  	mov	bp,[bp+6]
 17456 00000181 8ED0                    	mov	ss,ax
 17457 00000183 8CC4                    	mov	sp,es
 17458 00000185 8EC0                    	mov	es,ax
 17459 00000187 2E8B6E00                	mov	bp,[cs:bp]
 17460                                  
 17461                                  	; 21/10/2022 (MSDOS 5.0 SYSINIT code)
 17462                                  	;push    bp
 17463                                  	;mov     bp,sp
 17464                                  	;mov     ax,[bp+8]
 17465                                  	;pop     bp
 17466                                  	;push    es
 17467                                  	;pop     ss
 17468                                  	;mov     sp,bp
 17469                                  	;mov     bp,ax
 17470                                  	; 11/12/2022
 17471                                  	;;mov	bp,[cs:bp+0]	
 17472                                  	;mov	bp,[cs:bp]	
 17473                                  
 17474 0000018B 9C                      	pushf				; go execute the real interrupt handler
 17475                                  	; 11/12/2022
 17476 0000018C 2EFF5E00                	call	far [cs:bp]		;  which will iret back to here
 17477                                  	; 21/10/2022
 17478                                  	;call	far [cs:bp+0]
 17479                                  
 17480 00000190 89E5                    	mov	bp,sp			; retrieve the table offset for us
 17481                                  	; 11/12/2022

 18810 000006B6 E82A19                  	call	doconf			; do pre-scan for dos=high/low
 18811                                  
 18812                                  	; 11/12/2022
 18813                                  	; 27/03/2019
 18814                                  	; ds = cs (at return from doconf)
 18815                                  
 18816                                  ; Now, if this is not romdos, we decide what to do with the DOS code.
 18817                                  ; It will either be relocated to low memory, above the DOS data structures,
 18818                                  ; or else it will be located in HiMem, in which case a stub with the DOS
 18819                                  ; code entry points will be located in low memory. Dos_segreinit is used
 18820                                  ; to tell the DOS data where the code has been placed, and to install the
 18821                                  ; low memory stub if necessary. If the DOS is going to go into HiMem, we
 18822                                  ; must first initialize it in its present location and load the installable
 18823                                  ; device drivers. Then, if a HiMem driver has been located, we can actually
 18824                                  ; relocate the DOS code into HiMem.
 18825                                  ;
 18826                                  ; For ROMDOS, if DOS=HIGH is indicated, then we need to call dos_segreinit
 18827                                  ; to install the low memory stub (this must be done before allowing any
 18828                                  ; device drivers to hook interrupt vectors). Otherwise, we don't need to 
 18829                                  ; call dos_segreinit at all, since the interrupt vector table has already 
 18830                                  ; been patched.
 18831                                  
 18832                                  	; 22/10/2022 - Retro DOS v4.0
 18833                                  	; (MSDOS 5.0 IO.SYS - SYSINIT:0749h)
 18834                                  	;cmp	byte [cs:runhigh],0	; Did user choose to run low ?
 18835                                  	; 11/12/2022
 18836 000006B9 803E[6C02]00            	cmp	byte [runhigh],0
 18837 000006BE 740C                    	je	short dont_install_stub	; yes, don't install dos low mem stub
 18838                                  
 18839                                  ;------ user chose to load high
 18840                                  
 18841                                  	; 22/10/2022
 18842                                  	;mov	es,[cs:CURRENT_DOS_LOCATION] ; MSDOS 6.21 (& MSDOS 6.0)
 18843                                  	; 11/12/2022
 18844                                  	; ds = cs
 18845 000006C0 8E06[7302]              	mov	es,[CURRENT_DOS_LOCATION]

 19146                                  ;   Once we get to this point, the above code, which is below "retry"
 19147                                  ;   in memory, can be trashed (and in fact is -- see references to retry
 19148                                  ;   which follow....)
 19149                                  
 19150                                  retry:
 19151 00000782 BA[5846]                	mov	dx,commnd	; now pointing to file description
 19152                                  
 19153                                  ; we are going to open the command interpreter and size it as is done in
 19154                                  ; ldfil. the reason we must do this is that sysinit is in free memory. if
 19155                                  ; there is not enough room for the command interpreter,exec will probably
 19156                                  ; overlay our stack and code so when it returns with an error sysinit won't be
 19157                                  ; here to catch it. this code is not perfect (for instance .exe command
 19158                                  ; interpreters are possible) because it does its sizing based on the
 19159                                  ; assumption that the file being loaded is a .com file. it is close enough to
 19160                                  ; correctness to be usable.
 19161                                  
 19162                                  ; first, find out where the command interpreter is going to go.
 19163                                  
 19164 00000785 52                      	push	dx		; save pointer to name
 19165 00000786 BBFFFF                  	mov	bx,0FFFFh
 19166 00000789 B448                    	mov	ah,48h	; ALLOC
 19167 0000078B CD21                            int     21h             ; get biggest piece
 19168 0000078D B448                    	mov	ah,48h	; ALLOC
 19169 0000078F CD21                    	int	21h		; second time gets it
 19170 00000791 726B                    	jc	short memerrjx	; oooops
 19171                                  
 19172 00000793 8EC0                    	mov	es,ax
 19173 00000795 B449                    	mov	ah,49h	; DEALLOC
 19174 00000797 CD21                    	int	21h		; give it right back
 19175 00000799 89DD                    	mov	bp,bx
 19176                                  
 19177                                  ; es:0 points to block,and bp is the size of the block in para.
 19178                                  
 19179                                  ; we will now adjust the size in bp down by the size of sysinit.
 19180                                  ; we need to do this because exec might get upset if some of the exec
 19181                                  ; data in sysinit is overlayed during the exec.
 19182                                  
 19183                                  	; 22/10/2022
 19184                                  	; (MSDOS 5.0 IO.SYS SYSINIT:083Bh)
 19185 0000079B 8B1E[9402]                      mov     bx,[MEMORY_SIZE] ; get location of end of memory
 19186 0000079F 8CC8                    	mov	ax,cs		 ; get location of beginning of sysinit
 19187                                  
 19188                                  ; Note that the "config_wrkseg" environment data is a segment in
 19189                                  ; unallocated memory (as of the Dealloc of [area], above). This is ideal
 19190                                  ; in one sense, because Exec is going to make a copy of it for COMMAND.COM
 19191                                  ; anyway, and no one has responsibility for freeing "config_wrkseg". But
 19192                                  ; we need to make sure that there's no way Exec will stomp on that data
 19193                                  ; before it can copy it, and one way to do that is to make the available
 19194                                  ; memory calculation even more "paranoid", by subtracting "config_wrkseg"
 19195                                  ; from the "memory_size" segment value (which is typically A000h) instead
 19196                                  ; of the current sysinit CS....
 19197                                  ;
 19198                                  ; The reason I use the term "paranoid" is because this code should have
 19199                                  ; slid the data required by Exec up to the very top of memory, because as
 19200                                  ; it stands, you have to have sizeof(COMMAND.COM) PLUS 64K to load just
 19201                                  ; COMMAND.COM (64k is about what sysinit, and all the goop above sysinit,
 19202                                  ; consumes). Now it's just a little worse (65K or more, depending on
 19203                                  ; the size of your CONFIG.SYS, since the size of the environment workspace
 19204                                  ; is determined by the size of CONFIG.SYS.... -JTP
 19205                                  
 19206                                  	; 30/12/2022 - Retro DOS v4.2 (Modified MSDOS 6.21, IO.SYS)
 19207                                  	; (SYSINIT:0858h)

 19848                                  ; procedure : MovBIOS
 19849                                  ;
 19850                                  ;		Moves BIOS code into requested segment
 19851                                  ;
 19852                                  ;	In : ES - segment to which BIOS is to be moved
 19853                                  ;		  ( it moves always into offset BCode_Start)
 19854                                  ;
 19855                                  ;	Out : ES:DI - pointer to memory immediately after BIOS
 19856                                  ;
 19857                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 19858                                  
 19859                                  	; 23/10/2022 - Retro DOS v4.0 (Modified MSDOS 5.0 IO.SYS)
 19860                                  
 19861                                  ;ifndef ROMDOS
 19862                                  
 19863                                  MovBIOS: ; proc	near
 19864                                  	; 11/12/2022
 19865 000009C9 1E                      	push	ds ; ds = cs	
 19866                                  	;
 19867                                  	; 23/10/2022
 19868 000009CA 2E8E1E[8902]            	mov	ds,[cs:temp_bcode_seg]		; current BIOS code seg
 19869                                  	;mov	si,BCODE_START ; mov si,30h
 19870                                  	; 09/12/2022
 19871 000009CF BE[3000]                	mov	si,BCODESTART
 19872 000009D2 89F7                    	mov	di,si
 19873 000009D4 B9801A                  	mov	cx,BCODE_END ; mov cx,1A60h
 19874 000009D7 29F1                    	sub	cx,si				; size of BIOS
 19875 000009D9 D1E9                    	shr	cx,1				; Both the labels are para
 19876                                  						;  aligned
 19877 000009DB F3A5                    	rep	movsw
 19878                                  	
 19879                                  	; 11/12/2022
 19880 000009DD 1F                      	pop	ds ; ds = cs
 19881                                  	;
 19882 000009DE 06                      	push	es
 19883 000009DF 57                      	push	di				; save end of BIOS
 19884 000009E0 8CC0                    	mov	ax,es
 19885                                  	;
 19886                                  	; 11/12/2022
 19887                                  	;mov	[cs:BCodeSeg],ax		; save it for later use
 19888                                  	;;call	dword ptr cs:_seg_reinit_ptr
 19889                                  	;call	far [cs:seg_reinit_ptr]		; far call to seg_reinit (M022)
 19890                                  	; ds = cs
 19891 000009E2 A3[8403]                	mov	[BCodeSeg],ax
 19892 000009E5 FF1E[8702]              	call	far [seg_reinit_ptr]
 19893                                  	;
 19894 000009E9 5F                      	pop	di
 19895 000009EA 07                      	pop	es				; get back end of BIOS
 19896 000009EB C3                      	retn

 20013 000009F9 E86802                  	call	off_to_para			; convert to para

 20016                                  	;inc	ax ; + 1 paragraph for MCB
 20017 000009FC 09DB                    	or	bx,bx				; M012
 20018 000009FE 89C3                    	mov	bx,ax				;  can we use int 21 for alloc
 20019 00000A00 741A                    	jz	short update_arena		; M012
 20020 00000A02 B448                    	mov	ah,48h				; request DOS
 20021 00000A04 CD21                    	int	21h
 20022 00000A06 7250                    	jc	short FatalErr			; IF ERR WE ARE HOSED
 20023                                   	; 23/10/2022
 20024                                  	; 24/03/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0 (ORG 0)
 20025 00000A08 83E803                  	sub	ax,3				; Take care ORG 30h of
 20026                                  						;  BIOS code
 20027 00000A0B 8EC0                    	mov	es,ax
 20028                                  	;mov	word [es:20h+ARENA.OWNER],08h	; mark it as system
 20029                                  	;mov	word [es:20h+ARENA.NAME],'SC'	;  code area
 20030                                  	; 14/05/2019

 20032                                  	;mov	word [es:ARENA.NAME],'SC'	;  code area
 20033                                  	; 23/10/2022
